references.title: HTML AAM rules for the option element

examples: A screen reader will announce the name of the option (if present) in addition to the value.
Voice control software will let the user say something like "choose <name>" after saying something like "show choices" to pick the option.
A screen reader might announce "option" as the role.
A screen reader might not announce a role because the role is implied by the role of a select element, combo box, or listbox.
A screen reader might not announce a role because the role is implied by the announcement of auto complete or suggestions.
Voice control software will let the user say something like "move down <n>" or "move up <n>" to select an option.

assertions.title: convey the value of the option when used in a datalist context
assertions.rationale: When in a datalist context, both the name and value are displayed, so the user needs to be aware of both.
examples: A screen reader will announce the value of the option in addition to the name.
Voice control software will let the user say something like "choose <value>" to pick an option.

assertions.title: convey information about the position the option in the list
assertions.rationale: When user should be able to determine how many options are in the list and where they are in the list
examples: A screen reader might announce "choose <2 of 10>" when navigating through a list of options
